questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with gradually worsening shortness of breath and fatigue. He has a history of tuberculosis treated 10 years ago. Physical examination reveals elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP) that rises paradoxically with inspiration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Wave/ Descent

Refers

Clinical Significance

a Wave
  • Atrial contraction (right atrium), follows the P wave on ECG and precedes S1
  • Prominent in RV compliance issues
  • Early Prominent- Tricuspid stenosis
  • Late Prominent- Mitral stenosis
  • Absent in atrial fibrillation
  • Cannon a waves in AV dissociation and ventricular tachycardia.

x Descent
  • Fall in right atrial pressure post-a wave, reflecting atrial relaxation
  • Dominant in normal jugular venous pulses.
  • Prominent- Cardiac tamponade and constrictive pericarditis
  • Absent- Tricuspid Regurgitation

c Wave
  • Occurs during ventricular systole, tricuspid valve bulges into the right atrium
  • Seen in the ventricular systole
  • Can coincide with a carotid pulse.

v Wave
  • Passive Atrial filling after ventricular systole follows S2
  • Prominent in tricuspid regurgitation (TR)
  • In severe TR, the C wave may merge with the V wave, creating a "ventricularized" waveform—a giant V or CV wave.

y Descent
  • Fall in right atrial pressure after tricuspid valve opening
  • Absent in pericardial tamponade
  • Prominent in constrictive pericarditis or severe TR.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about grades of murmurs?

options.label: A
options.text: Grade 1 murmur is very loud and audible even without a stethoscope

options.label: B
options.text: Grade 2 murmur is faint but audible with a stethoscope.

options.label: C
options.text: Grade 4 murmur has a loud intensity without thrill.

options.label: D
options.text: Grade 6 murmur is very faint and heard with difficulty.

questions.correct_answer: B. Grade 2 murmur is faint but audible with a stethoscope.
questions.explanation:
Grade 1

Very faint, heard only with difficulty.

Grade 2

Faint but audible with a stethoscope.

Grade 3

Moderately loud, easily audible.

Grade 4

Loud, with a palpable thrill.

Grade 5

Very loud, with a palpable thrill, heard with the edge of the stethoscope.

Grade 6

Extremely loud, audible without a stethoscope, with a palpable thrill.

questions.text: Match the Following Murmurs to Their Characteristics or Associated Conditions Murmurs Characteristics or Associated Conditions 1. Mitral Stenosis A. High-pitched, crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border. 2. Aortic Stenosis B. Holosystolic murmur radiating to the axilla, often with a displaced apical impulse. 3. Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) C. Early diastolic decrescendo murmur best heard along the left sternal border. 4. Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy D. "Machine-like" continuous murmur heard best at the left infraclavicular area. 5. Mitral Regurgitation E. Loud S1, opening snap, and low-pitched diastolic murmur heard best at the apex. 6. Aortic Regurgitation F. Systolic ejection murmur, often with a crescendo-decrescendo pattern, best heard at the right upper sternal border, radiating to the carotids.
questions.explanation:
Mitral Stenosis

Low-pitched diastolic murmur with opening snap, best at the apex. Accentuated by exercise or Valsalva's maneuver. 

Aortic Stenosis

Systolic ejection murmur, crescendo-decrescendo pattern, radiating to carotids

Patent Ductus Arteriosus

A continuous, machine-like murmur, heard at the left infraclavicular area

Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy

Harsh systolic murmur, crescendo-decrescendo pattern

Mitral Regurgitation

Holosystolic murmur radiating to the axilla

Aortic Regurgitation

Early diastolic decrescendo murmur, best heard at the left sternal border

Graham Steell Murmur

Early diastolic decrescendo murmur due to pulmonary regurgitation, heard best at the left upper sternal border.

Austin Flint Murmur

Low-pitched, rumbling diastolic murmur due to severe aortic regurgitation causing turbulent flow in the left ventricle.

Carvallo's Sign

Increased intensity of a tricuspid regurgitation murmur with inspiration, heard along the left lower sternal border.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with exertional chest pain and dyspnea. On physical examination, you note a harsh mid systolic murmur that is loudest at the left sternal border and increases in intensity with the Valsalva maneuver. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Condition

Murmur Characteristics

Aortic Stenosis (AS)

(Option B ruled out)
  • Systolic murmur is loudest to the right of the sternum, radiating to the neck.
  • The intensity remains constant with maneuvers (unlike HCM).

Mitral Valve Prolapse (MVP)
  • Late systolic murmur is best heard at the apex.
  • Typically preceded by a non-ejection click, and intensity and duration increases with maneuvers that decrease ventricular volume.

Pulmonic Stenosis (PS)

(Option C ruled out)
  • Systolic murmur is best heard in the second and third intercostal spaces.
  • Intensity increases with severity but decreases with maneuvers that decrease pulmonary blood flow.

Atrial Septal Defect (ASD)

(Option D ruled out)
  • Midsystolic murmur is best heard at the left sternal border, due to increased pulmonary blood flow.
  • Typically has fixed splitting of the second heart sound.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a loud, high-pitched murmur heard best at the apex of the heart, radiating to the axilla. The intensity of the murmur does not change with inspiration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 7-year-old child is brought to the clinic for evaluation of high blood pressure detected during a routine check-up. On physical examination, the blood pressure is higher in the arms compared to the legs. A continuous murmur is heard over the back, near the left scapula. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Coarctation of the Aorta 
  • Narrowing occurs where the ductus arteriosus connects to the aorta, distal to the left subclavian artery.
  • Causes elevated blood pressure above the narrowing (upper limbs) and reduced blood pressure below it (legs).

Clinical Features
  • Can cause cardiac failure in newborns but may be asymptomatic in older children or adults.
  • Hypertension above narrowing may cause headaches; reduced blood flow below may lead to leg cramps or weakness.
  • Radio-femoral delay.
  • A continuous murmur is typically heard over the back near the left scapula.
  • Additional sound (ejection click) may be heard in the aortic area if a bicuspid aortic valve is present.
  • Collateral circulation develops through periscapular, internal mammary, and intercostal arteries, sometimes causing localized bruits

questions.text: In aortic regurgitation, capillary pulsations can be seen in the nail beds. What is this sign called?
questions.explanation:
deMusset's sign (Option C ruled out)

A head bob occurring with each cardiac cycle

Mueller's sign

Systolic pulsations of the uvula.

Becker's sign

Visible pulsations of the retinal arteries and pupils.

Quincke's pulses (Option A)

Visible Capillary pulsations in the nailbeds after holding the tip of the nail.

Duroziez's sign (Option B ruled out)

A systolic and diastolic bruit heard when the femoral artery is partially compressed.to and fro murmur

Traube's sign

A pistol shot murmur (systolic and diastolic sounds) heard over the femoral arteries.

Mayne's sign

More than a 15 mmHg decrease in DBP with arm elevation from the value obtained with the arm in the standard position.

Hill's sign

Popliteal cuff systolic pressure exceeding brachial pressure by more than 60 mmHg.

Rosenbach's sign

Systolic pulsations of the liver.

Gerhard's sign

Systolic pulsations of the spleen.

questions.text: From the list of ECG findings given below which will not be seen in mitral stenosis?
Which of the following schematic represents murmur of mitral stenosis?
questions.explanation:
Definition
  • Narrowing of the mitral valve, usually due to rheumatic disease, causing obstruction to blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle

Symptoms
  • Breathlessness
  • Fatigue
  • Oedema, ascites
  • Palpitation
  • Haemoptysis
  • Cough
  • Chest pain
  • Thromboembolism

Systolic murmurs

Diastolic murmurs

Midsystolic

  • Aortic stenosis
  • Pulmonic stenosis
  • Atrial septal defect
  • HOCM

Early diastolic

  • Aortic regurgitation
  • Pulmonic regurgitation
  • Austin-Flint

Holosystolic

  • Mitral regurgitation
  • Tricuspid regurgitation
  • VSD

Mid/late diastolic

  • Mitral stenosis
  • Tricuspid stenosis

Late systolic murmur

  • Mitral valve prolapse

Other rare murmurs

  • Patent ductus arteriosus

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with fatigue and a rapid, low-volume pulse. Chest X-ray is given below. What is the treatment?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Features
  • Fatigue
  • Rapid, low-volume pulse
  • Elevated JVP with rapid y descent
  • Loud early third heart sound (‘pericardial knock’)
  • Kussmaul’s sign (rise in JVP during inspiration)
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Ascites
  • Peripheral edema
  • Pulsus paradoxus (rare)

Investigations
  • Chest X-ray: May show pericardial calcification
  • Echo and cardiac catheterization to differentiate from restrictive cardiomyopathy

Management
  • Diuretics: Loop diuretics (Option A) and aldosterone antagonists (e.g., spironolactone)
  • Surgical resection: Diseased pericardium removal, though with high morbidity and variable outcomes

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman recently diagnosed with adenocarcinoma lung presents with sudden dyspnoea, tachycardia, and hypotension. Examination reveals elevated JVP and an abnormal drop of 15mm Hg in systolic blood pressure during inspiration. An ECG was performed and is given below. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

A 60-year-old man with a history of heart failure presents with worsening edema and jugular venous distention. You observe a steep x and steep y descent in the jugular venous waveform. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.explanation:
Wave/ Descent

Clinical Significance

a Wave
  • Absent in atrial fibrillation
  • Cannon a waves in AV dissociation and ventricular tachycardia.

x Descent
  • Absent x descent in tricuspid regurgitation (Option B ruled out)

v Wave
  • Prominent in tricuspid regurgitation
  • It may merge with the c wave in severe TR, creating a "ventricularized" waveform.

y Descent
  • Blunted in pericardial tamponade (Option C ruled out)
  • Steep in pericardial constriction and severe TR.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with palpitations and lightheadedness. His ECG shows an unequal number of P waves and R waves and his jugular venous pressure (JVP) tracing is shown below. Which of the following conditions is responsible for this finding?
questions.explanation:
a Wave
  • Occurs due to atrial contraction.
  • Follows P wave on ECG.
  • Precedes S1

Clinical Significance:

  • Prominent in reduced RV compliance
  • Absent in atrial fibrillation (Option A ruled out)
  • Cannon a waves in AV dissociation and ventricular tachycardia.
    • They occur when the right atrium contracts against a closed tricuspid valve, typically seen with AV dissociation.
    • In wide complex tachycardia, cannon ‘a’ waves in the jugular venous waveform suggest a ventricular origin of the rhythm.

questions.text: Loud first heart sound (S1) in mitral stenosis indicates?

A 70-year-old woman with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy, hypertension, and diabetes presents with worsening shortness of breath and fatigue. On physical examination, you hear both an S3 and an S4 heart sound. Which of the following best explains the presence of both heart sounds in this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Combined systolic and diastolic heart failure

questions.correct_answer: C. Combined systolic and diastolic heart failure

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with palpitations. On examination, hyperdynamic precordium is noted with soft S1 and pansystolic murmur. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Sound

Timing

Mechanisms

Characteristics

Variable Features

First heart sound (S1)

Beginning of systole

Mitral and tricuspid valve closure

Typically single or slightly split
  • Loud in conditions like anemia, pregnancy, thyrotoxicosis, mitral stenosis
  • Soft in heart failure, mitral regurgitation

Second heart sound (S2)

End of systole

Aortic and pulmonary valve closure (A2 first, P2 second)

Splits during inspiration; single on expiration
  • Fixed wide splitting with atrial septal defect
  • Wide variable splitting with delayed right heart emptying (RBBB)
  • Reversed splitting due to delayed left heart emptying (LBBB)

Third heart sound (S3)

Early diastole, after S2

Sudden deceleration of blood filling into ventricles

Low pitch, often heard as 'gallop'
  • Normal in young people and pregnancy
  • Pathological in heart failure, mitral regurgitation

Fourth heart sound (S4)

Late diastole, before S1

Atrial contraction against a stiff ventricle

Low pitch
  • Present in severe left ventricular hypertrophy
  • Absent in atrial fibrillation

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency department with episodes of palpitations, dizziness, and occasional chest discomfort. He mentions that the episodes are sudden in onset and can last for several minutes before resolving spontaneously. His vitals are stable, and physical examination is unremarkable. An ECG of the condition is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?

A 6-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents due to concerns about his difficulty keeping up with peers during physical activities. Inspection shows a prominent precordium. Auscultation reveals a systolic ejection murmur. What heart sounds will be heard in this case?

A 7-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a history of recurrent respiratory infections and exercise intolerance. On physical examination, a holosystolic murmur is noted at the left lower sternal border, and the child exhibits signs of left-to-right shunting. What is this condition most likely associated with?

A 45-year-old man presents with progressive dyspnea and occasional dizziness. On auscultation, a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur is noted at the left sternal border, which increases with the Valsalva maneuver. There is also evidence of a jerky carotid pulse. Which of the following will be heard on auscultation in this case?
Narrow split S2 heart sound is heard in which of the following conditions?

Match the following Condition Type of S2 Splitting 1) Wide Split a) RBBB 2) Paradoxical Splitting b) Mitral regurgitation 3) Fixed Splitting c) LBBB 4) Narrow Split d) Pulmonary artery hypertension e) ASD
questions.explanation:
Condition

Type of Split

1)Wide split

Mitral regurgitation

2)Paradoxical split

LBBB

3)Fixed Splitting

ASD

4)Narrowed splitting

Pulmonary artery hypertension

Wide Splitting
  • Occurs in conditions like right bundle branch block (RBBB) due to delayed pulmonic valve closure.
  • Seen in severe mitral regurgitation (MR) due to premature closure of the aortic valve- Wide and variable split is seen.

Narrow Splitting or Singular S2
  • Narrow Splitting- E.g. Aortic stenosis or Singular S2

Wide Fixed Splitting
  • The A2-P2 interval is wide and does not change during the respiratory cycle. E.g.- ASD, TAPVC, RVF

Reversed or Paradoxical Splitting- P2 before A2
  • Seen in conditions such as left bundle branch block (LBBB).
  • Right ventricular pacing.
  • Severe aortic stenosis (AS).
  • Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM),
  • Acute myocardial ischemia.

Loud P2
  • Considered loud when its intensity exceeds A2 at the base or can be palpated in the proximal main pulmonary artery area. E.g.- Pulmonary arterial hypertension.

Decreased Intensity
  • A2 intensity decreases with aortic stenosis (AS) and P2 intensity decreases with pulmonic stenosis (PS), potentially resulting in a single S2.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes with a history of fever, chest pain, weight loss, and night sweats. During a physical examination of a patient, the physician notes a characteristic sound that persists on breath holding. On further evaluation, she is found to have pericardial effusion on echocardiogram. What is this finding called on auscultation known as?
Which of the following features would raise suspicion for a diagnosis of Carney complex rather than sporadic cardiac myxomas?
questions.correct_answer: B. Presence of skin pigmentation abnormalities
questions.explanation:
Introduction
  • Most common primary cardiac tumors in adults.

Location
  • Often found in the left atrium.

Types
  • Sporadic.
  • Familial: Carney Complex (Myxomas + skin lesions + Endocrinopathies).

Clinical presentations
  • Obstructive symptoms resembling mitral valve disease (e.g., dyspnea, fatigue).
  • Embolic events: Risk of thrombus formation and systemic embolization.
  • Constitutional symptoms: Fever, weight loss, fatigue due to cytokine secretion.

Investigations
  • Echocardiography, CT, MRI, Histopathology.

Tumor Type

Characteristics

Clinical Considerations

Papillary Fibroelastoma
  • Friable tumors with frond-like projections.
  • Commonly found on cardiac valves.
  • Can cause valve dysfunction and embolization.
  • Generally resected.

Rhabdomyoma
  • Common in infants and children.
  • Multiple in ~90% of cases.
  • Associated with tuberous sclerosis (Option A ruled out).
  • May mimic valvular stenosis, CHF, or restrictive cardiomyopathy (Option C ruled out).

Hemangioma
  • Generally small, often intramyocardial.
  • May cause AV conduction (Option D ruled out) disturbances.
  • Potential for sudden death if near AV nodes.

questions.text: During the cardiac cycle, the closing of the aortic valve takes place at the?
questions.explanation:
Phases

Description

Protodiastole
  • Marks the earliest phase of diastole.
  • Ventricular pressures drop more rapidly in a fully contracted state of ventricular musculature.

Isovolumetric relaxation
  • Ventricular musculature relaxes in an uniform pattern with both AV and semilunar valves closed.

First rapid-filling phase
  • Marks the opening of AV valves followed by rapid ventricular filling.
  • Also known as the Passive filling phase (due to the difference in Atrial and ventricular pressures).

Diastasis
  • Pressures in the Atria and ventricles equal and ventricular filling rate declines rapidly and stops eventually.
  • This momentary period of least ventricular filling is known as Diastasis.

Last rapid filling
  • Eject out the remaining blood left by active atrial contractions.
  • Also known as the Active filling phase.

Phases Description
Isovolumetric Contraction

Marks the onset of systole.

Ventricles begin to contract with all valves closed, causing a rapid rise in intraventricular pressure without a change in volume.
Rapid Ejection Phase Begins when ventricular pressure exceeds aortic and pulmonary artery pressure, leading to opening of semilunar valves and rapid outflow of blood from the ventricles.
Reduced Ejection Phase Ventricular contraction weakens, causing ejection to slow down; although blood still flows out, the rate decreases as pressures in the ventricles and arteries begin to equalize.
